Like Blogger Revkin I grew up in the 1960's in awe of the world of Cousteau and similarly cherished my undersea exploration gear.  Unlike Revkin, I stood beside Captain Cousteau as he opened a new marine science building at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School in 1973 and have had various contacts with the man, the legacy and the family since.  As the excellent biography by Brad Matsen "The Sea King" reveals, Cousteau led a double life, that of the sterling master of the seas, on board the vessel he seldom visited, presented to American television and film viewers, along with the hidden wife and family, and descendants fighting over and using the name and legacy before and after his death.  The wily Frenchman was a complicated man whose legacy of speaking out for preservation of nature and the ocean endures, despite his flaws.  His pulpit was based on America's perceptions, which he carefully nurtured and controlled, and in the end he did accomplish the raising of awareness that would probably have otherwise not occurred.  While today he is lauded for speaking out on ocean pollution and the plight of fisheries, his most important efforts, started during the last years of his life, were to point out the underlying role of overpopulation of the planet in every aspect of environmental problems and to warn of the consequences.  The root cause of nearly every environmental and many social problems, the explosion of human population, was not being addressed and he courageously tried to bring it to world attention.  He largely failed and today, in the world of conservative religious fanaticism and political correctness from many sides, population control is almost a forbidden subject.  If Cousteau should be properly remembered, he should be lauded for speaking out in his last years about this threat and made the focus of renewed efforts to stem (much like that oil well in the Gulf of Mexico, whose very existence is a result of the pressure of human population) the tide of human population growth.

Re Post #35:

"I don't believe Adrian O's claim that he is a "math physicist", since such a title would imply that he knows something about the scientific method. Clearly Adrian has no idea how science works. I have it on good authority that deniers operate out of boiler rooms....".

In a recent blog post, Adrian O. provided information about his professional position, including a link to a university web site listing his name & names of fellow researchers. I would encourage Adrian O. to repost this link, so that all of us can examine his credentials.

More generally, I would prefer that we all refrain from personal attacks. At least let's ask an individual to provide some biographical information, before launching an attack on this person's character.

Note: In the past I've posted links to authors that are skeptical about some aspects of AGW science. Does this prove that I work in a boiler room; or that I'm a "pseudo-skeptic"? Hardly.

Personally, I've never been paid to write blog posts, nor have I ever held a job with any organization that would gain financially from an attack on AGW science or policy.

Let's try to keep the conversation convivial. (Ironically, this is Andy Revkin's explicit request for the video debate in this particular blog post!)

Larry G.
Seattle, WA

@JAB"
"What the Left fails to comprehend is that the First Amendment guarantees freedom "of" religion, not freedom "from" religion.

This oft-repeated statement is typical of shallow thinking. One cannot have guaranteed freedom of religion unless freedom FROM religion is also guaranteed.

Think about it. The Government must remain neutral in religious matters. Are you suggesting the Government should start imposing religion on everyone? What if the brand of religion it chooses to impose isn't the one you subscribe to? You'd be wanting freedom FROM religion then!

Freedom of religion must be freedom OF religion, meaning each person has right to choose his or her system of belief or lack thereof and has no right to force his or her belief upon another. This does not mean freedom FROM religion for everyone, as some would like it to mean, because freedom from religion as a chosen religious belief --the belief of the few with the most restrictive and intollerant belief system-- then becomes a forced freedom from religion enforced by the state, which is a direct violation of the very laws that those claiming the right to said enforcement often use in order to bring about this illegitimate enforcement. If freedom FROM religion is a religious belief qualifying for protection under religious freedom laws, then all court cases attempting to wipe from public view all religions is a violation of the religious freedom of everyone who has a contradictory religious belief, no matter what that belief may be, because it sets as the preference of the state the beliefs system of those who choose freedom FROM religion. Therefore the only way for freedom FROM religion cases to hold water is to determine freedom FROM religion to be a non-religious belief, in which case the "religious freedom" of those who lack religion cannot be infringed upon, as it is not religion in the first place, which invalidates pretty much every case.

Religious intollerance cannot be addressed by a systematic religious oppression of everyone. This idea that religions being suppressed will somehow improve anyone's life is nothing more than a modern man's crusade.
